docs.lead_paragraph: Evidence is building that high levels of the amino acid homocysteine, long linked to heart attacks, also increase the risk of strokes. The possible link between homocysteine and strokes is controversial, in part because no one knows for sure whether the substance actually causes them or whether lowering it protects against strokes.

headline.main: New Hints of Amino Acid's Link to Strokes

docs.abstract: Evidence is building that high levels of the amino acid homocysteine, long linked to heart attacks, also increase risk of strokes (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Children are taught that Samson was a hero who fought the Philistines and fell victim to Delilah's wily charms. But writing in a psychiatric journal, four physicians offer slightly different interpretations. They argue that the son of Manoah -- who lied to his parents, stole from his neighbors, brawled with regularity and killed with abandon -- is a classic example of someone suffering from antisocial personality disorder.

headline.main: Samson Diagnosis: Antisocial Personality Disorder, With Muscles

docs.abstract: Psychiatrists say Samson as described in Bible met six of seven established criteria for antisocial personality disorder, pervasive pattern of disregard for rights of others that begins in childhood, or early adolescence, and persists into adulthood; photo of Victor Mature, who played Samson in 1949 movie (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday after school, 9-year-old Ashley Moreno and a few classmates get together and play how-to-prevent-diabetes games -- not the sort of extracurricular activity that would thrill most fourth graders. But Ashley looks forward to the program, called Bienestar, Spanish for well-being.

headline.main: As Diabetes Strikes Younger, Children Get Lessons in Defense

docs.abstract: Pediatricians say that Type 2 diabetes, often considered an adult disease brought on by too much eating, is striking more teenagers, who are at risk for all of same consequences that afflict adults with diabetes, like diseases of eyes, heart and kidneys; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Last summer, as a 72-year-old friend exited from a strip mall in Connecticut, her car was struck broadside by an van she had not seen coming. She died three days later of complications related to her injuries. Just one year earlier, a 70-year-old woman I know was in a similar accident. She pulled out of a filling station on Long Island into the path of a semi. Her husband eventually died from his injuries; she survived, but after many hospitalizations and with permanent disabilities.

headline.main: Some Caution Signals for Older Drivers

docs.abstract: First of two Jane E Brody Personal Health column on added risks to road safety posed by older drivers; notes that by year 2020, one in five drivers will be 65 or older; describes vision deficits, body changes, congnitive changes and common health problems that can impairing driving of older people; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like a villain traveling incognito, the elusive germ that causes Lyme disease can disguise itself and evade vaccines by changing the chemistry of its outer coat with surprising complexity, scientists have found. This chemical virtuosity, they say, helps explain why the current Lyme vaccine has not been more protective. Dr. Aravinda M. de Silva, a microbiologist at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine and the chief author of a new study, said the findings should provide important clues for developing a more effective vaccine. The study shows that in fighting Lyme bacteria, or Borrelia burgdorferi, ''things are a lot more complicated,'' Dr. de Silva said in an interview.

headline.main: Findings Boost Hope for Better Lyme Vaccine

docs.abstract: Scientists find that elusive germ that causes Lyme disease can disguise itself and evade vaccines by changing chemistry of its outer coat with surprising complexity; say that this chemical virtuosity helps explain why current Lyme vaccine has not been more protective (M)
